llm_response.description: The image shows multiple dark blotches consistent with intraretinal hemorrhages scattered throughout the retina. There are also lighter areas that may represent exudates. The presence of these features suggests significant retinal changes.
The retinal image shows no significant abnormalities. The optic disc appears normal, and there are no visible signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, exudates, venous changes, or neovascularization.

The retinal fundus image shows signs of diabetic retinopathy. There are multiple microaneurysms and small hemorrhages scattered throughout the retina. Hard exudates are present, particularly in the temporal region. There is no evidence of neovascularization or vitreous/preretinal hemorrhage.

The retinal image shows a clear optic disc with no signs of neovascularization. The macula appears normal without any visible exudates or hemorrhages. There are no visible microaneurysms, cotton wool spots, or signs of venous beading. The retinal vessels appear normal without any signs of intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA) or hemorrhages.
The retinal image shows neovascularization near the optic disc and a large preretinal hemorrhage in the inferior region. These findings are indicative of proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

The retinal image shows multiple intraretinal hemorrhages, some of which are dense and widespread. There are also signs of venous beading in at least two quadrants. No neovascularization or vitreous hemorrhage is observed.

The retinal image shows a clear view of the optic disc and blood vessels. There are no visible signs of microaneurysms, hemorrhages, exudates, venous beading, intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA), or neovascularization. The retina appears healthy with no significant abnormalities.
